timeline.bodyText:
This applies to keySet, entrySet and values.  Do we want to support this calling Iterator.remove methods on the returned Collections?  If so it would be a custom implementation of the Collection returned and the Iterator would be able to track where we are with the current key, value, entry and be able to do the remove method based off of that.  With us having an array of getter/setter properties it will be easier to track what should be removed on the Collection iterator.
If we keep this current mechanism, then we should make a copy of the Set that is returned for super.keySet() like you do in entrySet so we aren't modifying the parents returned Set object.
timeline.author: jhanders34

replies.bodyText: So you decided to keep the current mechanism and not support Iterator.remove on the Set / Collection returned from keySet, entrySet and values?  If we do that we probably should have the Iterator remove return UnsupportedOperationException.  This is a change in behavior from the previous implementation of this classes where the Iterator would actually work.  I don't know if anyone calls keySet, entrySet or values on the MessageImpl class.
replies.author: jhanders34

timeline.bodyText: Should make a copy of the Map and then as you set fields instead of calling the super way of putting all, you should, remove them from the copy of the Map and only send the subset to the super.putAll
timeline.author: jhanders34

timeline.bodyText: I think there are additional methods that need to be implemented:  size, clear, isEmpty, containsValue, equals, hashCode, getOrDefault, forEach, replaceAll, putIfAbsent, remove(Object, Object), replace, computeIfAbsent, computerIfPresent, compute, merge.  We may want to just implement them and have them return UnsupportedOperationException if we don't think they are called by CXF.
timeline.author: jhanders34

replies.bodyText: So you implemented some as throwing UnsupportedOperationException. Was that intentional or you plan to implement those still?
replies.author: jhanders34

timeline.author: jhanders34

timeline.bodyText: Either this should call super.getOrDefault or this whole method should just call getOrDefault to use the impl that is in this class.
timeline.author: jhanders34

timeline.bodyText: Should check for NOT_FOUND here to avoid the .equals call.  Also you need to handle o being null or you are going to get a NullPointerException
timeline.author: jhanders34

replies.bodyText: I added a new comment for the changes.  Marking this one resolved.
replies.author: jhanders34

timeline.bodyText: This logic should be like the normal get method in this class.  Not sure why you aren't checking the propertyNames first.  You should use the keymap as well here like in get.   The method should be flipped and the last line be super.getOrDefault(key, d);
timeline.author: jhanders34

timeline.bodyText: This should be .equals instead of == check. Need to handle null as well.

I think this if / else can be simplified to:
propertyValues[index] = newValue == null ? NOT_FOUND : newValue;

If newValue is null it should set it to NOT_FOUND, i.e.
proeprtyValues[index] = newValue == null ? NOT_FOUND : newValue;

replies.bodyText: If remappingFunction == null this method should throw NPE.

jhanders34

timeline.bodyText: This will create an infinite loop.  clear() has the same issue.  You need to change to MessageImpl.this.size() and MessageImpl.this.clear();
timeline.author: jhanders34

replies.bodyText: Similar issue in the other impls as well.
replies.author: jhanders34

timeline.bodyText: Can you just use getOrDefault here like in other places instead of containsKey and get?  Will save doing a scan again
timeline.author: jhanders34

timeline.bodyText: Similar to the HashMap for keySet, values and entrySet, you can just have an instance variable that defaults to null and then make a key set, value collection, or entry set and set it if it is null.  You don't need to make one every time it is called.
timeline.author: jhanders34

timeline.bodyText: Not sure if this is called a lot, but for performance I think you can have this call putIfAbsent(key, v); instead of doing containsKey and put.
timeline.author: jhanders34

replies.bodyText: I think Andy wanted you to leave the comment you just removed and to remove the new comments you added.  The one you just removed has extra details that it is good not to lose.
replies.author: jhanders34

timeline.bodyText: I might be missing something, but I don't think these changes (this line, line 323, lines 327-328) are necessary.  IIUC, the only time that the MessageImpl is used is on line 340 which is already casted to a MessageImpl - and already surrounded by the change tags.
timeline.author: andymc12

replies.bodyText: inMessage is used after the DelegatingInputStream within the method.
replies.author: dettmoney

timeline.bodyText: If I read this right, we are pulling in the WadlGenerator source file and updating the bnd file just for this change.  I don't think very many customers use Wadl (it's pretty much been replaced by Swagger/OpenAPI).  Are you seeing specific performance improvements in your benchmarks with this change?  If so, I'd probably update the benchmarks to use OpenAPI instead. :) If not, I'd say let's undo this change and the bnd change - it's one less divergence from the Apache CXF repo.
timeline.author: andymc12

replies.bodyText: What API should I look for in my app to determine what's bringing in the WadlGenerator? I'm not explicitly using wadl (just pinging a simple REST endpoint). The only reason I changed that code is because it's showing up in the profiles as a caller into MessageImpl.get. JAXRSUtils.runContainerRequestFilters -> WadlGenerator.filter -> WadlGenerator.doFilter is the path I observe
replies.author: dettmoney

replies.bodyText:
That's unfortunate - it looks like we always load and register that provider... In the base CXF code, they only load it if the service.description module is on the class path - and we have it on the class path, so that means that we're executing that filter on every request...
To remove it now would probably break zero-migration - so we should probably fix it to be faster if possible.  Thanks
replies.author: andymc12

timeline.bodyText: I was hoping that you wouldn't need to have the getGetters, getSetters, getRemoves, getContains in MessageImpl.  You can build that dynamically using reflection and it will be less fragile and the test can automatically pick up new getters, etc and fail tests when new methods are added.
timeline.author: jhanders34

timeline.bodyText: This should be return e.equals(entry);
timeline.author: jhanders34
jhanders34

timeline.bodyText: This should be final
timeline.author: jhanders34
